texts.definition: The act of telling stories within the game.
markups: <style="Definition">The act of telling stories within the game.</style>

Many games tell stories as gameplay progresses. This might be through pre-produced material, through actions of those running the game, through the players themselves, or a combination. Regardless, this provides <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> to the gameplay experience.
Note: this pattern does not discuss the quality of Storytelling in a game, only how it relates to gameplay and game elements.
Note: this pattern does not discuss the retelling on gameplay events after it has occurred, for that see Game Instance Stories.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> do all have <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> as a part of them. However, while early <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style> supported this later games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Vampire:%20The%20Masquerade">Vampire: The Masquerade</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Universalis">Universalis</link></style> focused upon it (the former of these describes itself as a storytelling game rather than a roleplaying game). <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Once%20Upon%20a%20Time">Once Upon a Time</link></style> is a card game sharing many characteristics of <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> but by having removed the presence of player characters no longer is one. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/1942%20%E2%80%93%20Noen%20%C3%A5%20stole%20p%C3%A5">1942 – Noen å stole på</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Monitor%20Celestra">Monitor Celestra</link></style> have certain parts of the <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> pre-planned by game masters but rely heavily on players to bring the <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> to its full potential. Some <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based Roleplaying Games</link></style>, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Witcher%20series">Witcher series</link></style>, makes use of cutscenes to do part of their <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> while others, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20series">The Elder Scrolls</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>, tell their stories as part of gameplay only (with the exception of cutscenes that function as epilogues).

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Storytelling%20Games">Storytelling Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fiasco">Fiasco</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Once%20Upon%20a%20Time">Once Upon a Time</link></style> have a close relation with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> but as there name suggests focuses on <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sleep%20is%20Death">Sleep is Death</link></style> is a mediated two-player <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Game</link></style> where one of the players takes the role of a game master that tells a story to the other player.

On the most fundamental level, <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> in games requires <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> that perform actions as well as places and objects that they can interact with. <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, and especially <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>, is a natural starting point for <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> since they allow players a focus for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> between <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> is a classic way of motivating them as well as inviting for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> can be used to place the <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> in interesting situations, and may themselves provide stories through <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> can be used to create <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style> as part of gameplay, and may then include <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> as part of the <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Voiceovers">Voiceovers</link></style> is an approach to <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> games have adopted from movies, but this may work against <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style> is more or less short movies inside a game and can effectively do <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> but removes agency from players and needs to fit seamlessly with what has happened just before them to not break <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.

A main option regarding <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> is if the actual story to be told should be created before gameplay begins, i.e. providing the game with <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style>, or letting the <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> adapt to the gameplay or even drive it. <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> in games can be done both by <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> and by <style="Link"><link="entitled-players">Entitled Players</link></style>. The stories told do not have to be part of the <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structure</link></style> of a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> but can be in several different ways. First, they can be explanations of the history and current state of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternative%20Realities">Alternative Reality</link></style> of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> and this is the typical way <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> is done by <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> to advance the <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>. Second, the stories can be part of <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>, either providing backstories for <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or the retelling of previous gameplay within a <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. Providing back stories for <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> is an area where players usually are allowed <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> regarding <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style>, even in games with tightly restricted <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>. Third, the stories can be part of creating and expanding the <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> rather than unfolding an existing structure, although this requires <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style>.

As <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> is often used to describe series of gameplay events using diegetic terms, it is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Diegetic%20Patterns">Diegetic Pattern</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> can be used to make <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> in games show <style="Link"><link="emotional-attachment">Emotional Attachment</link></style>, but conversely the display of <style="Link"><link="emotional-attachment">Emotional Attachment</link></style> can be part of <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> can also be used to explain <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>) so that <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> is maintained. It can however also use game system concepts, e.g. "the orc took 3 hit points in damage" when describing the effect of an attack in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, and in this case tends to breaks <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.
Another diegetic use of <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> is to give diegetic motivations for <style="Link"><link="fudged-results">Fudged Results</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> gives both players and <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> the possibility to explain <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Information">Extra-Game Information</link></style> in a context which avoids disturbing <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> by players or <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> may be controlled through <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> or be <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style>. In contrast, the <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> done in computer games, for example by <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>, is a form of <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> that cannot be interrupted although they may be skipped.

<style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Narration%20Patterns">Narration Pattern</link></style>. In some games (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">LARPs</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="non-player-help">Non-Player Help</link></style> can be used to provide professional <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> skills.

<style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> either provides or creates <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> in a game. When <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> is performed by humans, it is a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> that often gives <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>, and being able to tell stories well can give <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Based%20Social%20Statuses">Game-Based Social Statuses</link></style> and can even be considered part of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> in games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Once%20Upon%20a%20Time">Once Upon a Time</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> can give players <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, and in games with <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, these stories can become part of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Constructed%20Worlds">Player Constructed Worlds</link></style> by being <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Decided%20Results">Player Decided Results</link></style>. In <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>, the stories can have further influence by being part of the development of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Never%20Ending%20Stories">Never Ending Stories</link></style>. This being said, <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> can be viewed as <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style> when they do not directly influence gameplay, or when only parts of them include making decisions about issues that affect the game state.

Besides being able to present and thereby create <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> can be used to frame all actions and events in these <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> within the <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> of an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternative%20Realities">Alternative Reality</link></style>, and can visualize <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and their histories. This often includes <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> of some types, and when players or human <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> do this it often a form of <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>. Of course, when the storytellers have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> they may also ruin the <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> by introducing unfitting objects or events or by making <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> do actions that does not fit their personality or competences. While <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style> in themselves tell stories, <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> done by <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> or players in <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style> where one cannot interrupt each other creates <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>. Being a storyteller can be a role players have, and successfully performing this can provide a sense of <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style>. It can also to a lesser degree be used to fulfill the role of a <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> one has adopted (this form of <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style> is more easily done through <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>).

<style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> can be used to focus players' interests on specific aspects of gameplay and the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>. This can be used to create an <style="Link"><link="illusion-open-space">Illusion of Open Space</link></style> in a game even when the gameplay area in limited.

<style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> and <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> can instantiate each other. <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> gives rise to <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> since here players create a story by what their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> do. In contrast, describing what their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> do is <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> but since this also describes their actions, and sometimes intentions, it create <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> as a consequence. <style="Link"><link="playing-lose">Playing to Lose</link></style> is a way of encouraging players to influence both <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> and <style="CurrentLink">Storytelling</style> so their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> have a bad but interesting story arc.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternative%20Realities">Alternative Realities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Information">Extra-Game Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Based%20Social%20Statuses">Game-Based Social Statuses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Never%20Ending%20Stories">Never Ending Stories</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Constructed%20Worlds">Player Constructed Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="fudged-results">Fudged Results</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="entitled-players">Entitled Players</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="emotional-attachment">Emotional Attachment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-player-help">Non-Player Help</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Voiceovers">Voiceovers</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="emotional-attachment">Emotional Attachment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Decided%20Results">Player Decided Results</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="playing-lose">Playing to Lose</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style>
